nodes.text: {P1 A0}     386. When animals are social, and so have the opportunity of learning not only from their parents but from other members of the species, the power of making useful mental acquirements is correspondingly great. It reaches a remarkable development even among insects some species ot which live together in great communities.

{P2 A0}   Young ants, for example, are tended with anxious care. It is said that they are led about the nest by older individuals and taught their duties. They are said to be playful  (Huber, confirmed by Fabre, Lesfourmis de la Suisse, 1874).
{P3 A0}   Most significant of all is the fact that some species have the habit of capturing slaves belonging to other species. These they take as pupae, never as adult ants.

{P4 A6}   [Huber says] “When the pupae hatch out in the nests of their captors, the young slaves begin their life of work, and seem to regard their masters' home as their own ; for they never attempt to escape, and they fight no less keenly than their masters in defence of the nest. ... In F. rufescens the males and fertile females do no work of any kind ; and the workers, or sterile females, though most energetic in capturing slaves, do no other kind of work."

{P5 A4}   Therefore the whole community is absolutely dependent upon the slaves. The masters are not able to make their own nests or to feed their own larvae. ... Huber shut up thirty masters without a slave and with abundance of their favourite food ... ; but they could not feed themselves and many died of hunger. He then introduced a single slave and she set to work at once, fed the surviving masters, attended to the larvae and made some cells.
